image.altText: A view of the Royal Adelaide Hospital.

props.synopsis: Doctors and nurses say patient care could be compromised if the SA government pushes ahead with plans to shift the infectious diseases unit out of Adelaide’s biggest public hospital and move it to a site across the road.

title.children: Hospital 'Tetris puzzle' could put SA patients at risk, tribunal hears

image.altText: Trucks and car travelling along a major road

props.synopsis: Community calls for a full duplication of the Sturt Highway have been back by South Australia's peak motoring body, which says planning needs to start now for the project to be realised.

title.children: Business owner's pre-election plea for highway duplication and safety

image.altText: A young woman embraces her medical equipment.

props.synopsis: Young South Australian woman Annaliese Holland is terminally ill, but she says being able to plan ahead has given her a sense of empowerment.

title.children: Annaliese likens her life to a 'field of landmines' — but planning has brought her peace

image.altText: A young man in a white polo shirt smiles in a radio studio

props.synopsis: Adelaide United defender Josh Cavallo, Australia's first openly gay professional footballer, says he still receives daily death threats since coming out more than three years ago.

title.children: A-League player reveals daily death threats since coming out as gay

image.altText: A group of people stand around a man in a suit speaking into a microphone at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Farmers pushed to the brink by drought have joined the state opposition on the steps of Adelaide's Parliament House calling for more government action.

title.children: SA farmers take 'gut-wrenchingly hard' drought battle to parliament

image.altText: A woman stands outside a gate

props.synopsis: Families and former workers say staffing ratios and profits are jeopardising good care at South Australian childcare centres, as data shows serious incidents are on the rise.

title.children: Former childcare educator speaks out over concerns with the sector

image.altText: An old wooden bridge crossing over a gorge with trees in the background.

props.synopsis: The South Australian Heritage Council has changed the name of a century-old bridge in the Riverland following concerns raised by the public, leaving a local station owner "bewildered".

title.children: Historic bridge renamed over 'negative mental health' concerns

image.altText: Paul Tilbury is wearing a suit but no tie

props.synopsis: Over two years, disability support provider Paul Kevan Tilbury falsely claimed more than $400,000 from the NDIS and used the cash to buy meals, jewellery, alcohol, tobacco and to install a home bar.

title.children: 'Shameful' NDIS provider jailed for fraudulently claiming $400,000

image.altText: An orange wave buoy rider in the ocean, words keep clean visible.

props.synopsis: It's been seven months since the Cape du Couedic wave buoy started malfunctioning off Kangaroo Island, with the BOM blaming supply issues in Canada for delays to a replacement.

title.children: No fix in sight for broken Bureau of Meteorology wave buoy

image.altText: South Australia batters and Queensland fielders shake hands

props.synopsis: Queensland's draw with South Australia will be enough to secure the Bulls a spot in the Sheffield Shield final if other results fall their way.

title.children: Queensland sets up Sheffield Shield final against South Australia

image.altText: A close of a woman's mouth as she eats a donut with pink frosting, sprinkles and a rainbow-coloured lolly on it.

props.synopsis: The CSIRO says the average Australian's diet is likely to get worse within five years, hurting our health and the taxpayers' purse. So what is standing in the way of better eating?

title.children: Australia's junk food problem is set to get worse. How do we fix it?

image.altText: A view of the Whyalla steelworks.

props.synopsis: Administrators of the Whyalla steelworks say they do not have enough funding to keep it running for 12 months, with the troubled industrial plant set to endure another blast furnace shutdown.

title.children: Whyalla steelworks in 'state of disrepair' as blast furnace faces new shutdown

image.altText: A person runs from a burning home.

props.synopsis: Detectives have seized one car and are searching for another linked to the alleged murder of a man at an Adelaide house which was later set on fire in what police say was an attempt by the two suspects to "cover their tracks".

title.children: CCTV shows murder suspect fleeing scene of burning home, police say

image.altText: A man dressed for freezing conditions hauls a sled across an icy landscape.

props.synopsis: Aaron Crook estimates he got 11 hours sleep in seven days as he trekked 620 kilometres across the Arctic Circle to win one of the world's toughest races.

title.children: SA man endures frostnip, hallucinations to win Arctic ultra-marathon

image.altText: A repair team fixes a drive-in screen with a crane.

props.synopsis: The community of Coober Pedy has banded together to reopen the outback town's outdoor cinema which draws in tourists during the cooler months.

title.children: SA's last drive-in repaired over scorching summer in time for tourist season

image.altText: dead octopus about the length of six mobile phones on a beach

props.synopsis: Dead octopuses have been found along South Australian beaches as environment authorities say a microalgae bloom could be to blame for fish deaths on the weekend.

title.children: Microalgae bloom likely cause after surfers reportedly falling ill at SA beach

image.altText: A screenshot of a video posted to RedNote shows Peter Dutton and the words "Dutton will not use Aboriginal flag".

props.synopsis: A series of attacks on Australian political parties on emerging Chinese social media platform RedNote raise concerns about misinformation, disinformation and the risk of foreign interference ahead of the federal election.

title.children: Deepfake Peter Dutton speaking Mandarin spotlights misinformation threat

props.synopsis: Reducing the time people spend job hunting has a broader economic benefit, with an independent report finding one charity helping women into the workforce has generated $86 million in net direct economic benefits over the past 20 years.

title.children: How helping women into the workforce is worth millions to the economy

image.altText: A young Israeli man with dark hair and wearing a green shirt standing among protesters in a street.

props.synopsis: The Israeli prime minister is facing fierce protests over his decision to launch fresh strikes in Gaza, shattering the ceasefire in the strip.

title.children: Thousands march on Netanyahu's home after latest Gaza strikes

image.altText: Antibiotics spread out on a table.

props.synopsis: As US big pharma comes for Australia's PBS, Labor is promising even cheaper medicines.

title.children: PBS medication to cost no more than $25 under Labor re-election pitch

image.altText: A teenage boy holding a plank of wood like a rifle in his kitchen while wearing a yellow bucket hat.

props.synopsis: The court heard that Nicholas Prosper had withdrawn into an online world and illegally bought a firearm as he plotted to carry out an attack on a primary school north of London.

title.children: British teen who murdered mother, brother and sister jailed for 49 years

image.altText: SpaceX dragon capsule entering the earth's atmosphere

props.synopsis: After 268 days without fresh air or a proper shower, Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams made their final journey back to Earth.

title.children: Inside the mission that brought NASA's 'stranded' astronauts home

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and red tie giving a speech outside a courthouse.

props.synopsis: Opposition figures and the foreign ministries of multiple countries have expressed alarm at a series of arrests, as members of Recep Tayyip Erdoğan's government reject allegations they are conducting a "coup".

title.children: Main rival to Türkiye's Erdoğan arrested just before presidential run

image.altText: A surveillance camera is silhouetted behind a Chinese national flag in Beijing.

props.synopsis: Beijing's spy agency said the man reportedly passed on information to an unnamed foreign power.

title.children: China sentences ex-engineer to death for alleged spying

image.altText: DRC Congo mining

props.synopsis: In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, battles are taking place for territory and rare earth minerals such as cobalt. Donald Trump is about to enter the race.

title.children: Is the Democratic Republic of the Congo next for Trump?

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks at a press conference at parliament house

props.synopsis: The opposition leader put his team on notice. He vowed he would remember the name of anyone who freelanced on policies. A month on, there's one name on the list of offenders — Peter Dutton.

title.children: Dutton won't need help identifying MP breaking his pre-election edict

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

props.synopsis:
Buying a carton of eggs at your local supermarket has become a lot harder in the past year.

The shelves are often bare, there's a limit on the number of cartons you can take home and prices are rising.

Today, Landline reporter Tim Lee explains how bird flu is leading to a major egg shortage and why it could last for years.

Featured:

Tim Lee, Landline reporter

title.children: How long will the egg shortage last?

image.altText: A picture of burnt out cars

props.synopsis: A Tesla service centre in Las Vegas has become the latest target in a series of attacks against the car maker, with the FBI blasting them as "unacceptable".

title.children: There's been an attack on Teslas. The FBI says it has 'hallmarks' of terrorism

image.altText: A blonde woman faces a press pack

props.synopsis: Keli Lane, the woman convicted of killing her baby daughter in one of Australia's most notorious criminal cases, has been identified in NSW parliament as a victim of convicted sex offender and former prison officer Wayne Gregory Astill.

title.children: Convicted baby killer Keli Lane named as victim of former prison officer

image.altText: Multiple packets of colourful pharmaceutical medicines.

props.synopsis: American medical giants want tariffs imposed on Australia as punishment for its Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which sees the government negotiate cheaper prices for medicines for Australians

title.children: US pharmaceutical giants urge Trump to put further tariffs on Australia

image.altText: A sign on the front of a building saying 'Genius Childcare', photographed through bars.

props.synopsis: Administrators have taken control of the majority of childcare centres run by teetering empire Genius.

title.children: Administrators take control over most of national childcare chain's centres

image.altText: High up view of crowds and an open top car with a man in a suit and a woman in a pink outfit sitting in the back seat

props.synopsis: Conspiracy theories, new timelines and suspicions of KGB links were among the 80,000 pages of documents, many blurred and damaged by age.

title.children: New JFK files reveal assassin's trip to Soviet embassy before attack

image.altText: Mark Carney standing behind a podium delivering a speech in front of the Canadian flag

props.synopsis: For months, senior officials have been discussing exporting Australia's world-leading JORN radar technology to the United States, but after Donald Trump's return to the White House, Canada saw an opportunity and leapt.

title.children: Australia's 'biggest defence export' was meant for the US first, but Canada snuck past Trump

image.altText: murder victim Lilie James in a car wearing a yellow top smiles as she takes a selfie

props.synopsis: Lilie James was smiling and talking to her killer moments before her death with "no indication" of what he was going to do, an inquest has heard.

title.children: CCTV of Lilie James moments before her murder 'not easy to watch'
